attribute.name: color

level.language: Electric crimson or red is a color whose hue resembles that of blood, or a ruby, and is of the long-wave extreme of the visible spectrum. Red is also a primary color. The hex for this color is #FF003F and the first known word usage was before the 12th century.
Electric Crimson
icon-color-red
color||Color||Electric crimson or red has always been one of your favorite colors and you will always choose that color over any other!||icon-color-red

Orange is a color between red and yellow that is like the color of fire and carrots. It is also a fruit that grows in California and Florida. The hex for this color is #FF9966 and the first know word usage was in 1542.
Orange
icon-color-orange
color||Color||Orange has always been one of your favorite colors and you will always choose that color over any other!||icon-color-orange
color||Color||Orange has always been one of your favorite colors and you will always choose that color over any other!||icon-color-orange

Yellow is having the color of the sun, butter, or ripe lemons. Yellow is also a primary color. It can be mixed with the other 2 primary colors to make lots of other colors but no colors mixed together can make yellow. The hex for this color is #ffd500 and the first known word usage was before the 12th century.
Lemon Yellow
icon-color-yellow
color||Color||Yellow has always been one of your favorite colors and you will always choose that color over any other!||icon-color-yellow

Green is a color whose hue is between yellow and blue and is associated with growing fresh grass, an emerald, Spring, evil, or envy. A person can also be "green with envy." The "Wicked Witch of the West" was green. The hex for this color is#009900 and the first known word usage was before the 12th century.
Green
icon-color-green
color||Color||Green has always been one of your favorite colors and you will always choose that color over any other!||icon-color-green

Gray is a series of neutral colors ranging between black and white and is often the color associated with age, usually depicted gray or silver hair. Also Gray is also the color associated with cloudy days and clouds filled with rain, hence the saying, "it's a gray day today." The hex for this color is #848482 and the first known word usage was before the 12th century.
Battleship Gray
icon-color-gray
color||Color||Gray has always been one of your favorite colors and you will always choose that color over any other!||icon-color-gray

Blue is a color whose hue is that of the clear sky, water, and is the portion of the color spectrum lying between green and violet. Blue is also a primary color. It can be mixed with the other 2 primary colors to make lots of other colors but no colors mixed together can make blue. The hex for this color is #007af3 and the first known word usage was before the 13th century.
Blue
icon-color-blue
color||Color||Blue has always been one of your favorite colors and you will always choose that color over any other!||icon-color-blue

Purple is any of various colors that fall about midway between red and blue in hue, an is often the color worn as an emblem of rank or authority. The hex for this color is #4b0082 and the first known word usage was before the 15th century.
Purple
icon-color-purple
color||Color||Purple has always been one of your favorite colors and you will always choose that color over any other!||icon-color-purple

Black is a word that has many, many meanings. Examples are typically associated with evil as in "black magic", a VERY bad mood, having the very dark color of coal, the night sky, something served without cream or milk as in "black coffee", or even used to describe humor that deals with subjects which are usually regarded as very serious or unpleasant. To make the color black, mix all of the other colors together and voila!, you get a mess, or black. The hex for this color is #000000 and the first known usage was before 12th century.
Starry Night
icon-color-black
color||Color||Starry night has always been one of your favorite colors and you will always choose that color over any other!||icon-color-black

Maroon is a variant of the color red and is considered a dark red color. The word maroon comes from the French word maroon which means "chestnut". Vajrayana Buddhist monks wear robes that are colored various shades of maroon. To make maroon start with red, add some blue and a little black and there you have it! Crayola introduced the maroon crayon to their pack in 1949. The crayola crayon hex for this color is #C32148 and the first recorded use of maroon as a color name in English was in 1789.
Maroon
icon-color-maroon
color||Color||Maroon has always been one of your favorite colors and you will always choose that color over any other!||icon-color-maroon

attribute.language: Color is defined as the phenomenon of light (as red, brown, pink, or gray) or visual perception that enables one to differentiate otherwise identical objects.
Shift the sliders to indicate a GREATER or LESSER preference for the colors shown.
color||Electric crimson or red has always been one of your favorite colors and you will always choose that color over any other!||icon-color-red

attribute.name: size

level.language: Small, in this case, refers to having comparatively little size or slight dimensions. The first known word usage was before the 12th century.
Small
icon-size-small
size||Size||You tend to like things that are small and compact in nature.||icon-size-small
Medium, in this case, refers to something in a middle position. The first known word usage was in 1589.
Medium
icon-size-medium
size||Size||You tend to gravitate toward things that are medium in size - not too big and not too small.||icon-size-medium
Large, in this case, refers to exceeding most other things of like kind especially in quantity or size. The first known word usage was before the 12th century.
Large
icon-size-large
size||Size||You like things that are big and large in size or quantity.||icon-size-large
Extra large, in this case, refers to large or great in dimensions, bulk, or extent. The first known word usage was before the 12th century.
Extra Large
icon-size-xlarge
size||Size||You like things that are extra large! The bigger the better and more the merrier!||icon-size-xlarge

attribute.language: Size, in this case, refers to physical magnitude, extent, or bulk, relative or proportionate dimensions or as one of a series of graduated measures especially of manufactured articles (as of clothing) conventionally identified by numbers or letters.
What size should your product be?
Shift the sliders to indicate GREATER or LESSER importance for the sizes shown.

Size, in this case, refers to physical magnitude, extent, or bulk, relative or proportionate dimensions or as one of a series of graduated measures especially of manufactured articles (as of clothing) conventionally identified by numbers or letters.

attribute.name: weight

level.language: My product should be exceedingly light and should weigh next to nothing or be light as air.
0 or Light as air
icon-weight-0
weight||Weight||You like things that are very light and weigh next to nothing or light as air!||icon-weight-0
My product should weigh no more than 5 pounds because I am going to carry it in my arms or tote it around in my backpack for long enough to be a problem if it weighs more.
5 Pounds
icon-weight-5
weight||Weight||The maximum weight you will tolerate carrying for any length of time is 5 pounds - and even that is a stretch!||icon-weight-5
My product can weigh up to 10 pounds because I am going to carry it in my backpack or in my carry on luggage so I will not be directly stressed by the weight.
10 Pounds
icon-weight-10
weight||Weight||You're ok with a maximum weight of 10 pounds because you have no intention of carrying this around, except in a backpack or in carry on luggage.||icon-weight-10
My product can weigh 15 pounds or more because I am never going to be carrying it. It will sit on my desk either at work or home.
15 Pounds
icon-weight-15
weight||Weight||You're ok with a maximum weight of 15 pounds or more because you have not intention of every picking it up.||icon-weight-15

attribute.language: Weight is the standard or established amount that a thing should weigh. The first known word usage was in 1647.
How much should your product weigh?
Shift the sliders to indicate GREATER or LESSER importance for the weights shown.
weight||You're ok with a maximum weight of 15 pounds or more because you have not intention of every picking it up.||icon-weight-15

attribute.name: intuition

level.language: No education is needed. You can use this product with little or no instruction.
Completely intuitive
icon-intuition-completely-intuitive
intuition||Product intuition||You like things that are completely intuitive, are really, really easy and need no instruction to use.||icon-intuition-completely-intuitive
Someone with a grade school education will be able to use this product.
Grade School
icon-intuition-grade-school
intuition||Product intuition||You like things that are so easy that someone with a grade school education can figure it out. A very little bit of instruction is ok.||icon-intuition-grade-school
Someone with a junior high school education can use this product.
Junior High school
icon-intuition-junior-high-school

intuition||Product intuition||You like things that are easy and someone with a junior high school education can use it. Some instruction is ok, but you don't want to have to ask your kids for help.||icon-intuition-junior-high-school
You need at least a high school education to use this product.
High School
icon-intuition-high-school

intuition||Product intuition||You like things to be a bit challenging and a high school education is about as much as you need to use it. Easy instructions are ok, but you're glad there are kids around, just in case.||icon-intuition-high-school
You need a college degree to use this product.
College
icon-intuition-college
intuition||Product intuition||You love a challenge but will need a college degree to figure it out. For most people instructions are a must!||icon-intuition-college
You need a graduate degree to use this product.
Graduate School
icon-intuition-graduate-degree
intuition||Product intuition||You love to be challenged and are glad you have a graduate degree to figure it out because without one, this would be no fun at all!||icon-intuition-graduate-degree
Without a doctorate you'll never figure this product out.
Doctorate
icon-intuition-doctorate

intuition||Product intuition||You LOVE a wicked challenge and because you have a doctorate, or very smart friends, you think this is great fun!. Even the instructions are unintelligible. What could be better!||icon-intuition-doctorate

attribute.language: In a perfect world, your product will be easy for anyone to use and figure out, but this is not a perfect world. How intuitive is your product?
How intuitive does your product need to be?
Shift the sliders to indicate a GREATER or LESSER preference for the level of intuition shown.

attribute.name: delivery

level.language: You want same-day delivery for time-sensitive stuff because it's really important.
Same day

5 days

delivery||Delivery||You can wait 5 days for delivery, but just barely.||icon-delivery-5-days

7 days

delivery||Delivery||You're not so impatient that 7 days will kill you to wait for delivery.||icon-delivery-7-days

attribute.language: For some people, speed is of the essence and for others, they can wait until the cows come home! So the question is, how impatient are you?

Select the delivery speed most important to you.

This question asks you to choose your top preference from a set of several options.

Click on or tap your top selection.
delivery||You're not so impatient that 7 days will kill you to wait for delivery.||icon-delivery-7-days

resource.name: welcome
resource.language: Understanding your product and service needs is important to us.

The product you choose is at the very core of your business and one of the most important decision you will have to make. Although the perfect product may or may not exist, there are definitely ways to minimize risk by choosing a product that have more going for it, than against it. Using specific criteria can help you better understand the product you are considering and increase your overall chances of success.
It only takes a few minutes...

Copyright Ⓒ 2019 TrueChoice Solutions, Inc. | Privacy Policy
The Starbucks word mark and the Starbucks Logo are trademarks of Starbucks Corporation. Starbucks is also the owner of the Copyrights in the Starbucks Logo and the Starbucks Card designs. All rights reserved.Starbucks is not a participating partner or sponsor in this offer.

resource.name: consent
resource.language:
Your consent is required to continue with this application.


Please return to the application to give your consent if you want to continue.


If you do not want to give your consent, you may close this browser tab to exit the application.

Your consent is required to continue with this application.


Please return to the application to give your consent if you want to continue.


If you do not want to give your consent, you may close this browser tab to exit the application.

resource.name: attrselect
resource.language: We'd like to understand your preferences for different tools and solutions that could potentially benefit your business

resource.name: intro
resource.language: The purpose of this survey is to understand what you prefer and value most from the compensation and benefits offered to you.

This exercise will take 10 minutes to complete.

Your responses are private and anonymous - there is no risk in being totally honest.

Please Note:

• This exercise needs to be finished in one session. You can't save your work, come back, and complete it later.


• This tool will time out after 30 minutes of inactivity. If that happens, you will have to start over from the beginning.


• If you need help, click or tap on the icons throughout the application.

resource.name: onboardintro
resource.language: The core part of this tool is divided into three sections:

1. What rewards options do you prefer?
For each rewards offering, share your preferences across a range of offering amounts.

2. How important is each rewards category?
Rate the importance of each category relative to the others.

3. How would you tradeoff rewards?
For pairs of rewards packages, tell us how much you prefer one over the other.
If you need help, click or tap on the icons.

resource.name: prestage1
resource.language: We are going to ask you about your preferences for option within a number of categories. For each option shown, select a value between 0 and 10. The lower the number, the less you prefer an option. The higher the number, the more you prefer the option.

resource.name: levels
resource.language: Shift the sliders to indicate GREATER or LESSER importance for the elements shown.

Shift the sliders to indicate GREATER or LESSER importance for the elements shown. The sliders have been pre-set in order of generally accepted preferences. Therefore, you cannot move a slider above the one to its right or lower than the one to its left.
If this characteristic is irrelevant to you, click Next and you will not be asked about it again.
What are we asking you to do here?

This question is asking you to state your preferences across a range of items.

Please indicate how much you prefer or value each item - in relation to the others - by moving the slider to a GREATER or LESSER preference or value for each of the elements shown. How far you move the slider depends on how strongly you feel about the item.

You cannot have the same preference value for all the choices shown.
First, we'd like to ask you about your preferences for items that inspire you create and develop a new product in areas including color, size, weight, shape and price.

resource.name: prestage2
resource.language: In Part 1, you rated the importance of options within each of a number of categories. Now it's time to rate the importance of each category relative to the others.

resource.name: attributes
resource.language: For each of the categories below, indicate its importance relative to the others by moving the slider towards the right (more important) or towards the left (less important).
What are we asking you to do here?

This screen lists the categories we asked you about in the first part of this application. Now, we'd like to understand how important each of these categories are relative to one another.

As you consider each category, your most and least preferred choices from Part 1 appear to remind you of your earlier responses.
Next we will ask you to rate the options from section one against each other. Please click or tap each option to indicate its importance to you and your product.

resource.name: prestage3
resource.language: Using what you told us in Parts 1 and 2, we've built personalized, hypothetical offerings for you to compare. Now it's time to weigh their appeal relative to one another.

resource.name: tradeoffs
resource.language: Assume all your choices are identical in every way except for the features shown. Based on the strength of your preference, slide towards the combination you prefer.
What are we asking you to do here?

Assume all your choices are identical except for the features show. Based on the strength of your preference, move the slider towards the combination you prefer.

We don't just want to know which option you prefer; we want to know how much you prefer it. We'll use this information to refine our understanding of your preferences.

Next we will show several different feature combinations based on the level of importance you place on these option in section two. Based on the strength of your preference, tap on the combination you prefer. If the displayed combination is unimportant to you, click next and move onto the next combination.

resource.name: prestage4
resource.language: We have a few additional questions that we'd like to ask you. As with the prior sections, any information you provide will be kept confidential.

resource.name: aboutyou

resource-element.value: What is the likelihood that you will answer all of these questions? Question
How much energy do you use per year Question

resource.language: Please take a moment to tell us a little about yourself:
This is a mock tooltip for stage.
Not so optional questions about you because all of the these fields are REQUIRED.

Almost done! Now we just have a few questions that we'd like to ask you. Any information you provide will be kept completely confidential and will not be shared with any third party. These questions are completely optional.

profile-key.language: TrueChoice Solutions, Inc. is a data analytics company that will collect your product and service preferences data. This will help BrandCo develop future product and service strategies that benefit your business.

TrueChoice Solutions, Inc. will share your data with BrandCo for the duration of this 2 month project. We will collect product and service preferences and customer satisfaction information. We will analyze the data in the United States.
Do you consent to tracking with Facebook Pixel?
To learn more about how TrueChoice Solutions, Inc. will manage your data and about your data privacy rights, click or tap here.

BrandCo will control the data collected from you by TrueChoice Solutions, Inc. BrandCo's contact information is:

E-mail: privacy@email.com
www.BrandCo.com

TrueChoice Solutions, Inc. would like to understand the value specific solutions to provide your organization.
The following screens will present different prodict categories and solutions and ask you to indicate how valuable each is to your organization.

Please select at least three product categories below. If there is an area that you have very limited familiarity with, you may opt to skip that category.
We encourage you to provide your viewpoint on as many of the categories as possible.
